sentences.text: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB- is a critical function of an Automatic Speech Recognition -LRB- ASR -RRB- System working on real applications where spontaneous speech , out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words and acoustic noises are present .

In this paper we present a new UV procedure with two major features : a -RRB- Confidence tests are applied to decoded string hypotheses obtained from using word and garbage models that represent OOV words and noises .
Thus the ASR system is designed to deal with what we refer to as Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities .
b -RRB- The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests , two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information , applied in a hierarchical structure .

Experimental results from a real telephone application on a natural number recognition task show an 50 % reduction in recognition errors with a moderate 12 % rejection rate of correct utterances and a low 1.5 % rate of false acceptance .

Entity-utterance_verification.label: Utterance Verification
Entity-utterance_verification.description: Utterance Verification (UV) is a crucial process in Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems that enhances performance by validating decoded speech against spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-uv_procedure.label: UV procedure
Entity-uv_procedure.description: The UV procedure refers to a novel method for Utterance Verification in Automatic Speech Recognition systems, which employs confidence tests on decoded string hypotheses to enhance recognition accuracy in the presence of out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-uv.label: UV
Entity-uv.description: UV refers to Utterance Verification, a critical function in Automatic Speech Recognition systems that enhances performance in handling spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-the_asr_system.label: the ASR system
Entity-the_asr_system.description: The ASR system refers to an Automatic Speech Recognition system that incorporates Utterance Verification to effectively handle spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise, enabling it to perform Word Spotting and Noise Spotting tasks.

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a new utterance verification procedure for automatic speech recognition systems, featuring confidence tests applied to decoded string hypotheses to enhance performance in recognizing spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noises.

Entity-experimental_result.label: Experimental results
Entity-experimental_result.description: The term 'Experimental results' refers to the quantitative outcomes obtained from testing a new utterance verification procedure in an Automatic Speech Recognition system, specifically demonstrating a 50% reduction in recognition errors, a 12% rejection rate of correct utterances, and a 1.5% false acceptance rate in a natural number recognition task.

Entity-out-of-vocabulary_-lrb-_oov_-rrb-.label: out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words
Entity-out-of-vocabulary_-lrb-_oov_-rrb-.description: Out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words refer to terms or expressions that are not included in the predefined vocabulary of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system, posing challenges in accurately recognizing and processing spontaneous speech.

Entity-correct_utterance.label: correct utterances
Entity-correct_utterance.description: Correct utterances refer to the accurately recognized spoken inputs in an Automatic Speech Recognition system that are accepted by the system after applying utterance verification procedures.

Entity-asr.label: ASR
Entity-asr.description: ASR refers to Automatic Speech Recognition, a technology system that processes and interprets human speech in real-time applications, particularly in the presence of spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-three_different_confidence_test.label: three different confidence tests
Entity-three_different_confidence_test.description: The term 'three different confidence tests' refers to a set of evaluations used in an Automatic Speech Recognition system's Utterance Verification procedure, consisting of two tests based on acoustic measures and one based on linguistic information, organized in a hierarchical structure to enhance recognition accuracy.

Entity-noise_spotting.label: Noise Spotting
Entity-noise_spotting.description: Noise Spotting refers to the capability of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system to identify and manage acoustic noises in speech recognition tasks.

Entity-rejection_rate_of_correct_utteran.label: rejection rate of correct utterances
Entity-rejection_rate_of_correct_utteran.description: The rejection rate of correct utterances refers to the percentage of correctly recognized spoken inputs that the Automatic Speech Recognition system decides to reject during the utterance verification process, indicating the system's performance in distinguishing between valid and invalid inputs.

Entity-real_application.label: real applications
Entity-real_application.description: The term 'real applications' refers to practical scenarios in which Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems are utilized, particularly those involving spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-asr_system.label: ASR system
Entity-asr_system.description: An ASR system, or Automatic Speech Recognition system, is a technology that enables the conversion of spoken language into text by processing audio input and recognizing speech patterns.

Entity-recognition_error.label: recognition errors
Entity-recognition_error.description: Recognition errors refer to the inaccuracies or mistakes made by an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system when interpreting spoken input, specifically in the context of a natural number recognition task.

Entity-word_and_garbage_model.label: word and garbage models
Entity-word_and_garbage_model.description: The 'word and garbage models' refer to representation models used in Automatic Speech Recognition systems to handle out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises during the process of utterance verification.

Entity-oov.label: OOV
Entity-oov.description: OOV refers to 'out-of-vocabulary', which denotes words that are not included in the vocabulary of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system, particularly in the context of handling spontaneous speech and acoustic noises.

Entity-word_spotting_and_noise_spotting_.label: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities
aliases: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities
Entity-word_spotting_and_noise_spotting_.description: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities refer to the features of an Automatic Speech Recognition system that enable it to identify out-of-vocabulary words and distinguish between speech and acoustic noise during utterance verification.

mentions.local_name: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities

Entity-word_spotting.label: Word Spotting
Entity-word_spotting.description: Word Spotting is a process or capability in automatic speech recognition systems that involves identifying specific words within spoken language, often in the presence of background noise.

Entity-confidence_test.label: Confidence tests
Entity-confidence_test.description: Confidence tests refer to statistical evaluations used in the context of Automatic Speech Recognition systems to assess the reliability of decoded string hypotheses, particularly in handling out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-automatic_speech_recognition.label: Automatic Speech Recognition
Entity-automatic_speech_recognition.description: Automatic Speech Recognition refers to a technology and system that enables the conversion of spoken language into text by processing audio input and recognizing speech patterns.

Entity-real_telephone_application.label: real telephone application
Entity-real_telephone_application.description: A real telephone application refers to a practical implementation of an Automatic Speech Recognition system that processes natural language input over telephone lines, specifically designed to handle spontaneous speech and recognize natural numbers while minimizing recognition errors.

Entity-noise.label: noises
Entity-noise.description: In the context of Automatic Speech Recognition systems, 'noises' refers to acoustic disturbances that can interfere with speech recognition, including out-of-vocabulary words and other unwanted sound signals.

Entity-acoustic_noise.label: acoustic noises
Entity-acoustic_noise.description: Acoustic noises refer to unwanted or extraneous sounds that can interfere with the performance of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system, particularly in environments where spontaneous speech and out-of-vocabulary words are present.

Entity-telephone_application.label: telephone application
Entity-telephone_application.description: The 'telephone application' refers to a practical implementation of an Automatic Speech Recognition system used for recognizing natural numbers in spoken language over telephone communications.

Entity-garbage_model.label: garbage models
Entity-garbage_model.description: Garbage models are representations used in Automatic Speech Recognition systems to account for out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises during the decoding process.

Entity-natural_number_recognition_task.label: natural number recognition task
Entity-natural_number_recognition_task.description: The natural number recognition task is a cognitive or computational task focused on identifying and interpreting spoken or written natural numbers.

Entity-decoded_string_hypothesis.label: decoded string hypotheses
Entity-decoded_string_hypothesis.description: Decoded string hypotheses refer to the outputs generated by an Automatic Speech Recognition system that represent the interpreted text from spoken language, particularly in the context of handling out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-out-of-vocabulary.label: out-of-vocabulary
Entity-out-of-vocabulary.description: Out-of-vocabulary refers to words or terms that are not included in a given vocabulary set, often posing challenges in natural language processing and speech recognition systems.

Entity-oov_word.label: OOV words
Entity-oov_word.description: OOV words refer to terms that are not included in a predefined vocabulary list, often encountered in natural language processing and linguistic analysis.

Entity-rejection_rate.label: rejection rate
Entity-rejection_rate.description: The rejection rate is a statistical measure that quantifies the proportion of instances or cases that are not accepted or are discarded in a given process, often used to evaluate the performance of systems in distinguishing between acceptable and unacceptable outcomes.

Entity-false_acceptance.label: false acceptance
Entity-false_acceptance.description: False acceptance refers to an error type in which a system incorrectly identifies an unauthorized entity as authorized, often measured in performance metrics related to security and recognition tasks.

Entity-acoustic_measure.label: acoustic measures
Entity-acoustic_measure.description: Acoustic measures refer to quantitative assessments of sound properties, often used to analyze speech or environmental sounds in various research and evaluation contexts.

Entity-spontaneous_speech.label: spontaneous speech
Entity-spontaneous_speech.description: Spontaneous speech refers to natural, unplanned verbal communication that occurs in real-time, often characterized by informal language and the presence of hesitations or interruptions.

Entity-linguistic_information.label: linguistic information
Entity-linguistic_information.description: Linguistic information refers to data or knowledge that pertains to language, including its structure, meaning, and usage.

Entity-hierarchical_structure.label: hierarchical structure
Entity-hierarchical_structure.description: A hierarchical structure is an arrangement of elements in a ranked or graded order, where each level is subordinate to the one above it, commonly used to organize information, roles, or processes.
